description: Early 15th century Middle English noselyng, as nose + -lyng (“(frequentative)”) (modern English nose +‎ -le (“(frequentative)”)). Modern affectionate, intimate sense 1590s, possibly influenced by nestle or nursle (frequentative of nurse).

verbs.description: nuzzle (third-person singular simple present nuzzles, present participle nuzzling, simple past and past participle nuzzled)

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) (of animals, lovers, etc) To touch someone or something with the nose.
examples: The horse nuzzled its foal's head gently to wake him up.
The bird nuzzled up to the wires of the cage.
She nuzzled her boyfriend in the cinema.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) To nurse; to foster; to bring up.
(obsolete) To nestle; to house, as in a nest.
(obsolete) To go along with the nose to the ground, like a pig.
examples: He charg'd through an army of lawyers, sometimes with sword in hand, at other times nuzzling like an eel in the mud.
